MEMBERS OF THE BOARD ADAM McMULLEN Governor PRANK MARSH Secretary of State L. B. JOHNSON State Auditor W. M. STBBBINS State Treasurer T. E. WILLIAMS State Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the constitu- tion of 1920. Prior therto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board oi Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commis- sioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commissioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY W. H. OSBORNE Ouster WM. H. SMITH Seward T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton NAME COUNTY SERVED SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923, to Jan. 12, 1925 April 18, 1923, to Jan. 12, 1925 T. E. LETTER OF TBANSMITTAIi December 1, 1928. Hon. Adam McMullen, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Sir: Herewith is transmitted the annual report of this department for the year 1928. In doing so I want to express the appreciation of the department for the co-operation of yourself and the other members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment. I also want to express my thanks to the County Assessors and County Clerks of the state for their help, and to the other county officers upon whom it has been necessary to make frequent calls for co-operation. Yours very truly. T. E. WILLIAMS, State Tax Commissioner.

60 REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 2 Intangible Property All property of this kind is divided into two classes, "A" and "B". Class "A" is made up of all kinds of money and is taxable at the rate of 2J4 mills on the dollar. Class "B" is made up of all other kinds of intangible property and is taxable at the rate of five mills on the dollar. The assessment of stock in banks, loan companies, trust and investment companies is included in Class B for this year in accordance with a decision rendered by the Supreme Court. The total amount of Class A returned for taxation for the year is $65,534,007, and the total amount of Class B is $107,028,284. The total amount of taxes that will be paid by intangibles for the year 1928 is $698,976.60 which will be distributed as follows: State General Fund _ $116,496.10 County General Fund - _ 116,496.10 Local City General Fund .„ . ♦232',992.20 Local School General Fund _ _ '232,992.20 $698,976.60 * Approximate The different items of intangibles assessed in each county are as follows: CLASS A CLASS B COUNTIES 1 2 Shares in Shares in Valuation I Foreign Corp. 66 REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER STATEMENT NO. 3 ASSESSMENT OF RAILROAD COMPANIES In 1921 the Chicago and Northwestern and the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha R. R. Companies were permitted under an order of the United States District Court to pay 75% and 60% of their assessments, respectively. A special master in chancery was appointed and testimony taken in regard to their valuation as well as to the valuation of other property, more particularly real estate. It was finally decided by the Master and affirmed by the Court that these companies were over-assessed and that other properties were assessed at only 70% of their actual value. The finding was appealed by the State to the United States Supreme Court and this Court affirm - ed the decision of the lower court. In the meantime, similar actions were commenced each year by the above-named roads for the years 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925 and 1926, and by the Chicago, Burlington & Quincy for the years 1922, 1923, 1924, 1925 and 1926; by The Missouri Pacific Railroad Cor - poration in Nebraska for the years 1924, 1925 and 1926; The Chicago, Rock Island, Pacific Railroad Company for the years 1925 and 1926. For each of these years, under an order of the United States District Court these Companies were permitted to withhold 25% of their taxes. The C. St. P. M. & O. was permitted to withhold 40%. Special masters in chancery were appointed by the Court to take testimony in regard to the valuation of the companies as well as the valuation of other property. The testimony for the years 19 22-23 and 24 was all submitted and the Special Master for the year 1923, (Mr. B. H. Dunham of Omaha) made a report of his findings to the court on December 31, 1927. The Special Master for the year 1922, (Mr. D. H. McClenahan of Lin - coln) made a report of his findings to the court on March 14, 1928. Synopsis of Master's Findings in 1923 Cases Property other than railroads assessed at 75% of its actual value. Synopsis of Master's Findings in 1922 Cases Property other than railroads assessed, at 75% of its actual value. STATE OF NEBRASKA 67 Actual value of Northwestern In Nebraska $ 33,500,000 Actual value of M. & O. in Nebraska % 8,500,000 Exceptions were filed by each of the parties to the above findings. The Federal Court issued decrees in the Burlington cases neither ap- proving nor disapproving the findings of the Special Master, but fixing the assessment of the Burlington at 75% of its actual value in Ne- braska for each of the years. The assessments as fixed by the Federal Court are as follows 1922 $109,000,000 1923 109,000,000 1924 110,000,000 1925 110,000,000 1926 110,000,000 1927 110,000,000 Decrees were also issued in the Northwestern cases fixing the assessment for each of the years as follows 1922 $ 29,035,779 19 23 29,041,655 19 24 29,075,812 1925 29,075,812 1926 29,075,540 Decrees were also issued in the M. & O. cases fixing the assess- ment for each of the years as follows: 1922 $ 7,435,743 1923 7,435,743 1924 7,435,743 1925 6,692,168 1926 6,739,432 The Rock Island cases were not referred to Special Masters, being decided by the Court itself. Decrees were issued by the Court fixing the assessment of the Rock Island for each of the years as follows: 1925... $ 7,199,204 1926 7,199,204 1927 7,199,204 The Missouri Pacific cases were all disposed of by a decree of the Federal Court on November 30, 1927. The Union Pacific and all of the smaller railroads paid the fall amount of taxes assessed against them during these years.

REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER 68 The Legislature of 1927 enacted a law which provided that the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, in making these assess - ments, should show how it arrived at the valuation of the various companies. This the Board did in 1927 and it resulted in a reduc - tion of about thirty-two million dollars in the railroad's assessment. With the exception of the Burlington and Rock Island, the assessment (or 1927 was satisfactory to all of the roads. At the time the 1928 assessment was made decisions had been given by the court in a number of the cases which were pending. The Board in making the 1928 assessment, followed the new law and also the decision of the Federal Court. This resulted in a further reduction of thirty-two million dollars of the railroad assessment. All of the railroad companies have accepted these assessments and are paying their taxes in full for this year. The order made by the State Board in making this assessment is submitted herewith. RESOLVED: That we, the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, in regular session held for the purpose of valuing and assessing the properties of the several railroad companies in Ne - braska for the purpose of taxation for the current year and having given due and full consideration to the returns furnished to this board by the several railroad companies and all of the additional evidence furnished by the several railroad companies, both oral and documentary, and to all of the evidence offered by the attorney general and to all the evidence offered by this Board upon its own motion, all of which evidence, with the objections thereto, is duly embodied in the record thereof in this office, and after having fully considered the arguments of counsel for the several railroad companies and being duly advised and informed in the premises, the Board finds the full actual value and the equalized value of the properties of the several railroad companies, respectively, for the year 1928, as follows: CHICAGO, BURLINGTON AND QUINCY RAILROAD CO. The actual value of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company is found by considering the market value of the stocks and bonds as of April 1st, 1928. The different items used in finding the value by this method are as follows:

REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER 80 which would be the assessment of the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railway Company, in Nebraska, as equalized, for the year 1928. ST. JOSEPH AND GRAXD ISLAND RAILROAD COMPANY The stock of the St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad is nearly all owned by the Union Pacific Railroad Company. This stock is not listed on the stock exchange and it is impossible to determine the value by considering the market value of the stocks and bonds. The value of this company is determined from the findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission as of June 30, 1919 with net addi - tions and betterments to December 31, 1927, plus 25%, for increased land values and increased unit costs. The different items used to arrive at the physical value as of this date are as follows: Interstate Commerce Commission value as of June 30, 1919 with net additions and betterments to De- Allocation The percentage which the all track mileage in Nebraska bears to the all track mileage of the system is 43.65%. Allocating the $9, - 713,801 on this basis gives $4,240,074 as Nebraska's share of the actual value of the road. Equalization Equalizing this value at 75% gives $3,180,056 as the equalized value of the St. Joseph and Grand Island Railroad Company for the year 1928. STATE OF NEBRASKA 101 Boiling Stock Assessment The rolling stock assessment of the various railroad companies is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in ac- cordance with Section 5874, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska, for 1922. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal prop- erty which is made by the local assessor and equalized by the State Board. STATE OF NEBRASKA 127 STATEMENT NO. 7 State Levy For 1028 RESOLUTION WHEREAS, from the auditor's report it appears that there was appropriated to be paid out of the general fund the sum of $13,239,272.41 for the biennium one-half of which should be met for the current year, which is $ 6,619,636.20 To meet which it is estimated there will be available miscellaneous collections for the general fund not otherwise appropriated $ 980,000.00 General Fund collections to be derived from Intangible Taxes 116,429.40 1,096,429.40 $ 5,523,006.80 which amount is increased 4% in accordance with House Roll 189, Session Laws of 1927 220,928.27 Leaving to be raised from the 1928 General Fund levy 5,744,135.08 The assessed value of the tangible property of the state as of record in the office of the Tax Commissioner Is $3,125,855,462 A levy of 1.84 mills will raise 5,751,573.93 The Capitol Fund levy as fixed by law is .22 of one mill and on the assessed valuation of the state will raise 687,688.18 THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED that the levies for 1928 be made as follows: GENERAL FUND 1.84 mills 5,751,573.93 CAPITOL FUND 22 mills 687,688.18 Total 2.06 mills $ 6,439,262.11
